speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the weakness and decreased sensation in your right arm, when did you first notice these symptoms and have they been constant or intermittent?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, it started a few weeks ago, I'd say. At first, it was just a slight numbness, but now it's gotten to the point where I'm dropping things all the time. It's pretty much constant, but some days are worse than others, and it's been getting progressively worse over time."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you experienced any pain or tingling sensations in your right arm, or has it been more of a numbness and weakness like you mentioned? Can you also tell me if you've had any recent injuries or trauma to the area?

speaker: Patient
text: "Yeah, I'd say it's a mix of both, doc. There's definitely some numbness, but I also get this dull aching and burning sensation in my right arm, especially at night or when I'm lifting weights. And no, I haven't had any recent injuries or trauma to the area, just the usual wear and tear from working out."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your workout routine, specifically what types of exercises you've been doing and how often, and have you noticed any triggers that make the symptoms in your right arm worse? Have you also experienced any similar symptoms in your left arm or anywhere else in your body?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, I've been lifting pretty heavily, 4-5 times a week, focusing on my upper body. I've noticed that when I'm doing heavy lifts, like bench press or rows, the weakness and numbness in my right arm seem to get worse. I haven't really noticed any similar symptoms in my left arm, but I have been feeling pretty fatigued overall, and I've lost a significant amount of weight recently, which is unusual for me since I'm always trying to bulk up."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's helpful to know. Can you tell me more about this weight loss you've experienced, how much weight have you lost and over what period of time, and have you noticed any changes in your appetite or digestive habits? Have you also had any fever, chills, or night sweats that could be contributing to your fatigue?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, I'd say I've lost around 17 pounds over the past few months, which is pretty significant for me since I'm always trying to maintain a certain weight for competitions. My appetite has been a bit off, I wouldn't say it's decreased, but I just haven't been feeling like eating as much as I usually do. And no, I haven't had any fevers, chills, or night sweats that I can think of, just this overall feeling of fatigue and weakness, especially in my right arm."

speaker: Doctor
text: Have you noticed any difficulty with balance or coordination, or have you experienced any dizziness or lightheadedness, particularly when changing positions or standing up quickly? And can you also tell me if you've had any recent changes in your bowel or bladder habits, such as constipation or urinary retention?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, I don't think I've noticed any problems with balance or coordination, I mean, I'm still able to get around the gym and do my workouts without any issues. And as for dizziness or lightheadedness, I haven't really experienced that either, unless I've had a few too many drinks after a competition. As for bowel or bladder habits, I don't think there's been any changes, everything seems to be working normally in that department."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any muscle atrophy or wasting in your right arm, and have you experienced any difficulty with fine motor skills, such as buttoning a shirt or tying your shoes? And I'd also like to take a look at your reflexes, can you please hold out your arms and legs for me to examine?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, now that you mention it, I have noticed that my right arm does seem a bit smaller than my left, especially around the bicep area. And yeah, I've had some trouble with fine motor skills, like buttoning my shirt or tying my shoes, it's just not as easy as it used to be. Okay, here are my arms and legs, go ahead and take a look."

speaker: Doctor
text: Your reflexes seem normal, but I do notice some slight atrophy in the bicep area of your right arm. Can you tell me if you've noticed any difficulty with swallowing or speaking, or have you experienced any shortness of breath, and have you had any recent vaccinations or exposures to anyone with a similar illness?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, no, I don't think I've had any trouble swallowing or speaking, my voice seems fine and I can eat and drink without any issues. And as for shortness of breath, I'd say I get a bit winded when I'm lifting heavy or doing cardio, but that's pretty normal for me. As for recent vaccinations or exposures, I don't think so, I've just been around my usual crew at the gym and haven't really been around anyone who's been sick."

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if you've noticed any changes in your sensation or strength in your right arm when you're at rest versus when you're actively using it, and have you experienced any fasciculations or muscle twitching in your right arm? Have you also had any recent travel or exposure to toxins that could be contributing to your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, yeah, I'd say the weakness and numbness in my right arm are definitely worse when I'm using it, like when I'm lifting weights or even just carrying groceries. When I'm at rest, it's not as bad, but I still get this tingling sensation every now and then. And yeah, I have noticed some muscle twitching in my right arm, especially after a workout, it's like my muscles are jumping around or something. As for recent travel or exposure to toxins, I don't think so, I've just been sticking to my usual routine at the gym and at home, although I do use a lot of supplements and steroids as part of my bodybuilding regimen."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's interesting, the fact that you're experiencing muscle twitching and weakness in your right arm, especially with activity, raises some concerns. Can you tell me more about the supplements and steroids you're using, specifically what types and dosages, and have you noticed any correlation between their use and the onset of your symptoms?

speaker: Patient
text: "Doc, I'm using a pretty standard stack for bodybuilding, you know, testosterone, trenbolone, and some insulin-like growth factor. I'd say I'm taking around 500mg of testosterone per week, and 200mg of trenbolone. As for the IGF, it's a bit harder to quantify, but I'd say I'm using about 10mcg per day. To be honest, I did start increasing my dosage around the same time I started noticing these symptoms, so maybe there is a connection. But I've been using this stuff for years without any issues, so I'm not sure what's going on."

speaker: Doctor
text: That's very helpful to know, the fact that you've recently increased your dosage and started experiencing symptoms around the same time does suggest a possible correlation. Can you tell me if you've noticed any other symptoms such as acne, hair loss, or mood changes since starting this new regimen, and have you had your liver function tests checked recently? speaker: Doctor
text:
DIAGNOSIS READY: Steroid-induced neuropathy or myopathy.

The majority of the doctors agree that the patient's symptoms are likely related to their steroid use, with many citing the temporal relationship between the increase in dosage and the onset of symptoms as evidence for this correlation. While other potential causes such as cervical radiculopathy, brachial plexus injury, or peripheral neuropathy were considered, the normal test results and the patient's specific symptom profile make steroid-induced neuropathy or myopathy the most likely diagnosis.

The mention of Cholecystitis in the prompt appears to be an error, as it was not discussed by any of the doctors and is not related to the patient's symptoms or test results.
